channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius faces murder charge
item.description: South African Olympic and Paralympic athlete Oscar Pistorius faces a murder charge after his model girlfriend is shot dead at his Pretoria home.

item.title: Bute found in UK horse carcasses
item.description: Eight horses, killed in the UK, have tested positive for the painkiller bute and six may have entered the food chain in France, the Food Standards Agency says.

item.title: Miliband: We'd bring back 10p tax
item.description: A Labour government would bring in a "mansion tax" to fund the return of the 10p starting rate of tax, party leader Ed Miliband says.

item.title: Warren Buffett in $28bn Heinz deal
item.description: US billionaire Warren Buffett's investment firm Berkshire Hathaway is to buy food giant Heinz in a $28bn (£18bn) deal, the biggest to date in the food industry.

item.title: Bloody Sunday families £50,000 offer
item.description: The BBC has learnt that the families of those killed on Bloody Sunday have been offered £50,000 each in compensation.

item.title: Two missing in Cairngorms avalanche
item.description: Two people are missing and a man has been airlifted to hospital after an avalanche in the Highlands of Scotland.

item.title: Eurozone sees recession deepen
item.description: The eurozone recession deepened in the final three months of 2012, with the area's economy contracting by 0.6%.

item.title: Pope hints at secluded retirement
item.description: The outgoing head of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Benedict XVI, hints he will withdraw into seclusion after stepping down at the end of this month.

item.title: Man held over Chetham's school abuse
item.description: A man is arrested by police investigating allegations of historical sex abuse at Chetham's School of Music in Manchester.

item.title: 'Bulger killer images' appear online
item.description: The Attorney General is investigating after photographs said to show one of James Bulger's killers were allegedly posted on the internet.

item.title: LHC switches off for two-year break
item.description: The Large Hadron Collider shuts down for a two-year-long period of maintenance and upgrades that should see a near-doubling of its collision energies.

item.title: BBC News chief moves to radio role
item.description: The BBC's head of news, Helen Boaden, is to be director of BBC Radio and former culture secretary James Purnell is returning to the BBC as part of management changes.

item.title: Lab rats 'acquire sixth sense'
item.description: US researchers have effectively given laboratory rats a "sixth sense" using an implant in their brains.

item.title: Record spending by overseas visitors
item.description: A record amount was spent in the UK by overseas visitors last year, according to the the Office for National Statistics.

item.title: American and US Airways to merge
item.description: American Airlines and US Airways confirm plans for an $11bn merger, which would form the world's biggest airlines.

item.title: Manchester United profits rise
item.description: Manchester United reports a 74% rise in profits for the second half of 2012, on the back of rising commercial revenues.

item.title: Ministers criticised over horsemeat
item.description: The government's response to the horsemeat scandal has been criticised as "flat-footed" by a group of MPs, who call for greater testing of products.

item.title: HMRC told to 'get a grip' on fraud
item.description: Public Accounts Committee chair Margaret Hodge tells HM Revenue and Customs to "get a grip", after it misses a target to tackle tax credit fraud and error "by a mile".

item.title: A&E waits 'highest for a decade'
item.description: The number of people in England facing long A&E waits has risen by a fifth in a year - and is now at its highest level for a decade, a report suggests.

item.title: 'Safety concern gag' on NHS chief
item.description: Health service manager Gary Walker claims he was gagged by the NHS from speaking out about his dismissal and his concerns over patient safety.

item.title: School PE 'not strenuous enough'
item.description: Education inspectors warn that there is not enough strenuous activity in many of England's school PE lessons.

item.title: Two school boards withdraw burgers
item.description: Another Northern Ireland education board - the North Eastern - withdraws beefburgers from school menus over the horsemeat issue.

item.title: Police hold 11 over ransomware scam
item.description: A complex cybercrime network spreading ransomware designed to extort money has been shut down, police say.

item.title: Google sues BT in patent battle
item.description: Google sues BT in the US and UK as a counter-attack to the British firm's existing lawsuits against the search giant.

item.title: New owl species is described
item.description: A new species of owl discovered in Lombok, Indonesia, has been formally described by scientists.

item.title: 'No radiation' from N Korea test
item.description: South Korean experts say they have not detected any radioactive isotopes from North Korea's nuclear test, hampering efforts to assess the device.

item.title: Funeral for The Troggs' Reg Presley
item.description: The funeral of Reg Presley, the frontman of 1960s rock band The Troggs, takes place in Hampshire.

item.title: Lloyd Webber's £150,000 for theatre
item.description: The Andrew Lloyd Webber Foundation donates £150,000 to a theatre company for a pop-up auditorium which can fit on the back of a lorry.

item.title: Is romantic love a bad thing?
item.description: Our idealised notion of romantic love is actually the biggest enemy of long-lasting relationships, says Mark Vernon.

item.title: VIDEO: Dresden survivor's story
item.description: Sixty-eight years ago today, British and American Air Forces dropped more than 2,600 tonnes of high-explosive bombs on the German town of Dresden.

item.title: Lee has 'case to answer' - WPBSA
item.description: Stephen Lee has a "case to answer" over match-fixing allegations according to governing body WPBSA.

item.title: Prior predicts tensions over IPL
item.description: England's Matt Prior says players will become "frustrated" unless the ECB softens its stance towards the IPL.

item.title: Lydia Ko, 15, cards round of 63
item.description: Lydia Ko, 15, cards a 10-under-par 63 in her opening round at the Australian Women's Open in Canberra.

item.title: Briton Froome leads Tour of Oman
item.description: Great Britain's Chris Froome finishes second on the fourth stage of the Tour of Oman to take the overall race lead.

item.title: Fire mother 'tried to take own life'
item.description: A mother accused of killing her six children in a fire tried to take her own life after her husband's mistress left the family home, a court hears.

item.title: Prostitute rape gang members jailed
item.description: Three members of a gang who targeted and raped prostitutes in Bradford, including a future victim of "Crossbow Cannibal" Stephen Griffiths, are jailed for 12 years.

item.title: Father appeals over missing student
item.description: A fresh appeal is made for information on missing teenager David O'Halloran, who has not been seen since a night out in Stirling.

item.title: Third of Scots councils set budgets
item.description: A third of Scotland's local authorities will be debating and voting on their budget plans for the coming year.

item.title: Robinson's concerns on Kelly arrest
item.description: First Minister Peter Robinson says the arrest of the man convicted of the IRA Shankill bomb could have "grave consequences" for the political process.

item.title: Burger recall after horsemeat found
item.description: More than 9,000 burgers made for the UK market by a firm in the Republic of Ireland are recalled after some are found to contain horsemeat.

item.title: 400 jobs created by Virgin Media
item.description: Virgin Media says it is creating 400 jobs in Swansea, Manchester and Birmingham to meet growing demand for its TV and broadband services.

item.title: Test all supplies call on horsemeat
item.description: A call is made for local councils in Wales to be ordered to test all meat supplies entering the public sector food chain as the horsemeat scandal grows.

item.title: Ivorian sets himself alight in Rome
item.description: A man from Ivory Coast about to be deported from Italy sets himself alight at Fiumicino airport in the capital, Rome, Italian media reports.

item.title: Newcastle player in fraud arrest
item.description: Newcastle United player Cheick Tiote's car is seized by police after being arrested on suspicion of fraud.

item.title: 'White phosphorus' at Burma protest
item.description: Burmese police fired military-issue white phosphorus grenades to disperse protesters at a controversial copper mine, a new report alleges.

item.title: Japanese economy worse than forecast
item.description: Japan's economy has shrunk for the third straight quarter, underlining the challenges the new government faces in reviving growth.

item.title: Germany finds horsemeat in lasagne
item.description: Germany is the latest country to report horsemeat DNA in processed beef, as authorities across the EU are told to conduct tests.

item.title: India halts helicopter deal payments
item.description: India says it is freezing payments for a helicopter deal to Italian aerospace firm Finmeccanica over corruption allegations.

item.title: Colombia soldiers die in rebel clash
item.description: Heavy fighting between the army and left-wing FARC rebels in the southern Colombian province of Caqueta leaves at least seven soldiers dead.

item.title: Apple loses iPhone ruling in Brazil
item.description: Brazil's trademark office rules that Apple does not have exclusive rights to the iPhone name, but the US tech giant is already appealing the decision.

item.title: Islamists 'capture Syrian oil town'
item.description: Fighters from the Islamist al-Nusra Front have captured a town close to Syria's oil city of Hasaka, according to foreign-based anti-Assad organisations.

item.title: Teenager killed in Bahrain protests
item.description: A teenage boy in Bahrain has been shot dead during protests to mark the second anniversary of a failed uprising.

item.title: Morning-after pill use rises in US
item.description: Use of the morning-after pill in the US is on the rise, a trend driven largely by wider use among younger women, a major government study finds.

item.title: Dorner 'on mission' before gun fight
item.description: A man carjacked at gunpoint by a murderous former Los Angeles policeman describes coming face to face with America's most wanted man.

item.title: Nature's total eclipse of the heart
item.description: Valentine's Day in nature

item.title: Day in pictures: 14 February 2013
item.description: News photos over 24 hours: 14 February

item.title: In pictures: Rio de Janeiro's Carnival
item.description: Inside Rio de Janeiro's Sambadrome

item.title: In Pictures: Architectural Review Future Projects Awards
item.description: Architectural Review Future Project Award winners

item.title: In pictures: Pope Benedict XVI's life
item.description: Looking back at the career of Pope Benedict XVI

item.title: Building sites reveal unseen London
item.description: A photographic exhibition of construction sites

item.title: In pictures: Grammy Awards 2013
item.description: Images from the 55th Grammy Awards in Los Angeles

item.title: In pictures: Bafta Film Awards 2013
item.description: A look at the winners and attendees

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs are debating the prevention of sexual violence in conflicts.

item.title: VIDEO: Fan clips help Harlem Shake to chart
item.description: Thousands of viral video clips made by fans have helped propel Harlem Shake, a track by New York producer Baauer, into the top 25 of the UK's official midweek chart.

item.title: VIDEO: Villagers install own fast web cables
item.description: A rural community in Lancashire has decided to fit their own cables for a better broadband connection.

item.title: VIDEO: Massive landslip closes rail line
item.description: A massive landslide caused by the collapse of a slag heap at a colliery in South Yorkshire means rail services in the area will be disrupted for months.

item.title: VIDEO: Liverpool team fears racism in Russia
item.description: Liverpool will be the first team to play Zenit St Petersburg after some of the Russian club's fans declared publicly that they did not want any black players on their team.

item.title: VIDEO: Dorner 'said he would not kill us'
item.description: A couple taken hostage by former Los Angeles policeman Christopher Dorner who is accused of murder, have spoken out about what happened.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Safety concern gag' on NHS chief
item.description: Health service manager Gary Walker claims he was gagged by the NHS from speaking out about his dismissal and his concerns over patient safety.

item.title: VIDEO: School PE 'not strenuous enough'
item.description: There is not enough strenuous, physical activity in many of England's school PE lessons, education inspectors say.

item.title: VIDEO: How far would you go to propose?
item.description: Valentines day is traditionally noted as the most romantic day of the year, where many people exchange cards and buy gifts for their loved ones.

item.title: Three centuries of the dating industry
item.description: Three centuries of the dating industry

item.title: Viewpoints: Successes and failures of Benedict XVI
item.description: Assessing the successes and failures of a papacy

item.title: Private or state: Where do sportspeople go to school?
item.description: Which schools have the most sportsmen and women?

item.title: UK troops prepare for Helmand tour
item.description: UK troops set for Helmand as mission draws down

item.title: The heavy metal-loving church
item.description: The church that hosts emos, goths and heavy metal fans

item.title: I hired a fake Facebook girlfriend
item.description: BBC reporter Dave Lee on hiring a fake Facebook partner

item.title: Wildlife photos: How to take the best shots
item.description: Getting your wildlife images to stand out from the crowd

item.title: Delhi's No.1 ladies' taxi company
item.description: Business booms for Delhi's No.1 ladies' taxi company

item.title: How the NHS locks away its secrets
item.description: How the NHS locks away its secrets

item.title: Fast fibre: A community shows the way
item.description: A community shows the way, says Rory Cellan-Jones
